Award.AwardTitle: University of Hawaii Oceanographic Instrumentation CY2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made by the University of Hawaii to fund additional and replacement instrumentation for the R/V Kilo Moana, (KM), a 185? general purpose research vessel operated as part of the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) research fleet. The University of Hawaii (UH) supports two research vessels that provide platforms for research in the fields of oceanography, marine biology, geology and atmospheric science. They request funds to purchase oceanographic instrumentation and equipment in support of the multidisciplinary NSF/UNOLS projects to be undertaken on R/V Kilo Moana in 2012. In order of priority, they propose:

1) Acquisition of spares for EM 710 Multibeam Sonar $113,329
2) Multi-year plan to upgrade and maintain underway DAS on Kilo Moana $49,982
$163,311

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two of the Proposal Guidelines. They provide infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Hawaii (UH) supports two research vessels that provide platforms for innovative research in the fields of oceanography, marine biology, geology and atmospheric science. This grant provided funds to purchase oceanographic instrumentation and equipment in support of the multidisciplinary NSF/UNOLS projects to be undertaken on R/V Kilo Moana. Specific outcomes included the procurement of spare components for the ship’s Kongsberg EM710 multibeam sonar and computers and network components to upgrade the ship's underway data acquisition system.  Both of these outcomes were accomplished.  In addition, some funds were reprogrammed to allow the procurement of an ultrafreezer when the existing one began to fail.  Permission for this reprogramming was provided in March 2015.  These combined purchases provided shared-use equipment needed to allow the R/V Kilo Moana to collect and record scientific data and otherwise support its funded scientific investigations.

The R/V Kilo Moana routinely collects underway geophysical, oceanographic and meteorological data products that are archives in freely accessible national repositories under the coordination of the NSF-funded Rolling Deck to Repository (R2R) program.  The R/V Kilo Moana is at the cutting edge of research vessel technology and the University of Hawaii seeks to maximize her exposure to the public as part of the University's committment to outreach and education.  Graduate and undergraduate students routinely participate in State- and federally-funded research cruises.  The vessel has routinely hosted Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) interns in an effort to train future marine technicians.  In addition, primary and secondary school teachers and students are introduced to modern oceanographic practices during tours and the occasional, opportunistic day trip.
